citation.abstract: The compelling need for safe storage and transportation of H2 has made liquid-phase materials safer H2-carriers with a high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen density. Unlike thermal or electrocatalytic decomposition on precious metal catalysts, a photocatalytic route to decomposing these liquid-phase materials can offer triggered onboard production of H2 and help mitigate the safety issues concerned with H2 storage. We have investigated visible-light induced H2 evolution from aqueous hydrazine using CdS quantum dots (QDs) as metal-free photocatalysts. Hydrazine acts as a H2 carrier as well as a donor, giving rise to a visible-light induced H2 evolution activity as high as 33 mmol h(-1) g(-1) at pH 8. This has been achieved by the use of CdS QDs capped with S(2-) ligands. The use of larger ligands such as mercaptopropionic acid hinders the adsorption of hydrazine onto CdS QDs and significantly decreases the activity. The effect of pH on the hydrogen yield in aqueous hydrazine has also been examined.
citation.journal: Dalton Transactions: An International Journal of Inorganic Chemistry
citation.title: Hydrazine as a hydrogen carrier in the photocatalytic generation of H2 using CdS quantum dots

author.name: Inorganic News
author.description: News, comments and publications about Inorganic Chemistry.
